Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 24th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT); San Francisco, CA; October 18 - 21, 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 24th international conference on parallel architectures and compilation techniques (PACT) will be held in San Francisco, CA in October 2015. PACT is a multi-disciplinary conference that brings together researchers from hardware and software areas to present ground-breaking research in parallel systems ranging across instruction-level parallelism, thread-level parallelism, multiprocessor parallelism and large scale systems.
This award is to make travel scholarships available to students and universities not typically represented at PACT in order to improve the conference?s impact and outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to provide student travel support  to the 24th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT). PACT is a multi-disciplinary conference that brings together researchers from the hardware and software areas to present ground-breaking research related to parallel systems ranging across instruction-level parallelism, thread-level parallelism, multiprocessor parallelism and distributed systems.  PACT 2015 was held in San Francisco, CA between October 18 -21.  Overall, 160 people attended the conference, including national and international researchs from students through senior leaders in the field.

PACT has always been an occasion for graduate students to meet and interact with more senior researchers who many times are not otherwise accessible. We organized a large number of excellent tutorials and a ACM poster competition. In addition to the benefits of participating at the conference.  US based students had the possibility to interact with students, faculty and people from all over the world and become more agile in the global village we are living in.

We have announced the support opportunity using the PACT conference web site, as well as the mailing lists used for the main conference  publicity.  The application process requested two documents: 1) letter of application; and 2) letter of support from faculty advisor.  We have received 20 applications and have made 16 awards. During this process we have emphasized diversity and encouraged applications from STEM minorities.  We have awarded all requests from women applicants, for a final count of three.  The awardees have presented 11 papers, 2 conference posters and 3 ACM SRC poster entries. One of the applicants was selected as a ACM SRC finalist.
